title: TTSDS2: Resources and Benchmark for Evaluating Human-Quality Text to Speech Systems
author: C. Minixhofer (University of Surrey), O. Klejch (University of Surrey), P. Bell (University of Surrey), ..., J. Yamagishi (BBC R&D)
relevance_why: The TTSDS2 metric and resources align closely with current research needs for evaluating text-to-speech systems, which is central to Haohe Liu's focus on audio and speech.
background: Text-to-speech systems are evaluated using metrics that may not accurately reflect human quality, especially as synthetic speech approaches indistinguishable quality from real speech.
contribution: This paper introduces the Text to Speech Distribution Score 2 (TTSDS2) to improve the evaluation of TTS systems, achieving a better correlation with subjective human evaluations across multiple languages and domains.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods struggled with comparable metrics and often lacked validation against subjective evaluations, especially as TTS quality increased.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by using a distributional analysis comparing synthetic speech to both real speech and noise distributions, with higher correlation coefficients across diverse datasets.

key_innovation: The introduction of a multifactorial evaluation metric based on perceptual factors and the dynamic updating of a multilingual dataset allows for more robust and relevant TTS evaluation.
real_world_impact: This benchmark can enhance the development of TTS systems, facilitating applications in areas like assistive technology and entertainment where high-quality synthetic speech is crucial.
limitations: Some limitations include the computational requirements of the TTSDS2 metric and its inability to account for context in speech generation.

new_terms.TTS: **Text-to-Speech** refers to the process of converting written text into spoken words using computer-generated speech.
new_terms.Spearman correlation: **Spearman correlation** is a statistical measure of rank correlation, indicating how well the relationship between two variables can be described using a monotonic function.

open_sourcing: The datasets and the TTSDS2 evaluation pipeline are available at [github.com/ttsds/pipeline](https://github.com/ttsds/pipeline)
